awd_titl_txt: Increased Risk of Chronic Disease Due to Domoic Acid Exposure with Age
awd_abstract_narration:
Domoic acid (DA) is a toxin produced by a type of harmful algal bloom. Domoic acid accumulates in seafood products and can harm marine mammals and humans who consume contaminated shellfish. At high doses, DA is responsible for the neurotoxic illness known as amnesic shellfish poisoning (ASP), with clinical symptoms that include seizures, memory loss, coma, and death. The effects of chronic exposure to lower doses are less well understood. Recent seafood consumption studies by this research team revealed that some recreational harvesters exceeded the current regulated dose limit and/or were chronically exposed to DA weekly for at least six consecutive months and that the majority of this group is over 60 years of age. Aging is the single greatest risk factor for multiple chronic diseases, including those affecting brain, heart, and kidney function, all of which are also targets of DA toxicity. This study will investigate how the effects of domoic acid exposure change with age. As ocean conditions change, exposure to DA through seafood consumption is likely to increase as a result of increased frequency and severity of toxin producing blooms. Thus a better understanding of the effect of DA exposure on the risk of developing chronic disease and the mechanisms underlying long term health problems, especially in the elderly population, is critical for better management of these risks by regulatory bodies and improved communication with stakeholders. The research is jointly supported by NSF and by the National Institute for Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS).

The study has three specific aims. First, in order to test the hypothesis that aging increases susceptibility to acute DA toxicity the investigators will measure the effects of acute symptomatic DA exposure on cognitive, cardiac and renal function in young and old mice. Following an acute symptomatic exposure, they will quantify tissue pathology and dysfunction in three systems with known DA induced pathology - cognitive, cardiac, and kidney systems. Second, in order to test the hypothesis that aging increases the susceptibility to chronic DA toxicity they will measure the effects of chronic low-level DA exposure on cognitive, cardiac and renal function in young and old mice. The investigators have previously demonstrated that chronic low-level DA exposure caused reversible cognitive deficits. However, whether aging affects the susceptibility to and reversibility of chronic DA toxicity to cognitive, cardiac and renal function has not been examined. Finally, in order to test the hypothesis that mitochondrial oxidative stress underlies chronic DA toxicity in cognitive, cardiac and renal systems they will use the chronic DA exposure paradigm (aim 2) in a mouse model (mCAT) overexpressing catalase, a key antioxidant enzyme, in the mitochondria.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Washington South Lake Union Campus

por.por_cntn:
1) Major Activities

This award supported the following major activities

  1. Assessing whether aging increases the susceptibility to pathological effects of both short and long-term sub-acute DA exposure.
  2. Conduct dose response curve and DA tissue analyses in young and aged mice in multiple tissues.
  3. Analyzed cardiac function following 3week sub acute DA exposure
  4. Implemented a new global longitudinal strain analysis as a more sensitive measure of in vivo cardiac function
  5. Measured biochemical markers of cardiac and mitochondrial dysfunction in DA exposed mice
  6. Measured changes in the proteome in young and old mouse hearts treated with DA
  7. Measured mitochondrial functional changes in tissues from mice exposed to DA

2) Specific Objectives

  1. Test whether aging increases the effect of DA on neurobehavioral and cardiac function
  2. Test whether DA toxicity is associated with mitochondrial defects in multiple tissues.
  3. Test the hypothesis that DA exposure phenocopies aging on mouse cardiac function

3) Significant Results

  1. Aged mice are more susceptible to short term DA exposure. This is associated with elevated tissue levels of DA.
  2. 3 weeks of sub-acute DA exposure (e.g. no overt neurological symptoms) induces both diastolic and systolic cardiac dysfunction in young and old mice.
  3. 3 week DA exposure led to significant mortality in aged mice only.
  4. The effect of 3 week DA exposure on cardiac function in young mice mirrors 3 month sub-acute DA exposure.
  5. 3 week DA exposure leads to changes in the mouse cardiac proteome similar to those induced my age.
  6. There are few effects of DA exposure on the proteome of aged mouse heart, despite significant functional decline.
  7. DA exposure increases the frailty index in young and old mice

4) Key Outcomes

  1. The increased neurotoxicity to short term DA exposure and higher tissue and plasma DA levels suggests greater susceptibility in aged mice may be linked to slower clearance.
  2. Low level DA exposure leads to mild inhibition of mitochondrial function in laboratory mice.
  3. DA exposure leads to significant deficits in cardiac function in old and young mice.
  4. Low level DA exposure, absent of overt neurological phenotype, leads to significant increases in frailty measures in both young and aged mice.
  5. DA exposure induces age-like changes in the cardiac proteome of mice.
  6. Cardiac deficits are not reversible even after extended washout of DA exposure (2 month)
  7. A manuscript reporting cardiac results is in preparation.
  8. A manuscript reporting the mitochondrial results is in revision.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/14/2025
Modified by: David J Marcinek

1) Major Activities


This award supported the following major activities

Assessing whether aging increases the susceptibility to pathological effects of both short and long-term sub-acute DA exposure. 
Conduct dose response curve and DA tissue analyses in young and aged mice in multiple tissues.
Analyzed cardiac function following 3week sub acute DA exposure

Test whether DA toxicity is associated with mitochondrial defects in multiple tissues. 
Test the hypothesis that DA exposure phenocopies aging on mouse cardiac function

There are few effects of DA exposure on the proteome of aged mouse heart, despite significant functional decline.
